Science Vessal - First of all this is the only ship to begin at level 2. It has some powerful board manipulating skills including scrambling the enemy's movement and a tractor beam to drag your victims into your team's firing range. It's ultimate is an all consuming blackhole.

reviewText:
Stellar Impact is a game that promises customizable fleet design and space combat.  However, it fails to deliver on all fronts.

The game does not have a single player component; it is online multiplayer only.  While some may not consider this a problem, multiplayer games aren’t much fun with only one player.  When I tested the game, all of the servers were empty.  In other words, the game is dead.

It’s a shame that SI has no single player mode.  If it did, then it may be a passable title – assuming they put as much effort into the single player mode as they did the game’s copy protection.

So, to save anyone reading some money, here is the entire Stellar Impact game experience.
1.	Purchase
2.	Download and install
3.	Start the game
4.	Go to the SI game website to create a mandatory account
5.	Start the game
6.	Log in
7.	Enter the CD key included with the game
8.	Connect to an empty server
9.	Exit the game

I give Stellar Impact 0/10 washed up developers.

reviewText:
The most uderrated hidden gem of a game you will ever have the fortune to discover.

This game has by far some of the most tactical gameplay that you will encounter in a MOBA. Think 19th century pre-dreadnaught naval tactics meets sci-fi. That means momentum, fire arcs, crossing-the-T, manouvers, formations! Combine this with the level of customization available to each ship means that there is a depth to this game that will make the game very rewarding for tactically minded players, throw in some fleet composition in the pre-combat phase and you have grand strategy too.

The next best thing about this game is the community, although it is small. It may seem so small that it is dead... and yet every weekend you will see players flock from far and wide, messaging each other on steam and the unofficial teamspeak server to get that 6v6 rolling, and roll it will for 5-10 consecutive games or more. Sadly, without new blood any gaming experience begins to stagnate.

So I say give this game a go. Its on sale, spare change. It might be one of the best buys of the year for you.

This game looks great, and for the most part it is - the ships are detailed, and morph with each weapon and ability change, the maps are lovely with lots of routes to take, and the gameplay is pretty sweet.

However, on my first experience of playing the game, I got into a multiplayer game and was instantly ostracised for being a new player. I'm glad I only spent a few pounds on this piece of garbage, but even so It was a waste of money. Experienced players wonder why they get no game time, and then openly criticise new players.

I hope you enjoy watching your precious game crumble under it's own lack of community, and as the last servers are shut down to be reused as cloud storage for Xbox one savefiles, all your hours of gameplay will fall into obscurity under the crushing disappointment that is Stellar Impact.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game. Do not pick it up. It is conceptionally flawed in a way that prevents any newbie to win against a veteran player. I bought this game during a sale, because its concept was nice. Back then, it was a few months after release, the game was almost dead already. (It is dead right now)

The game was fun for the first couple matches, because there were a good amount of newbies and 2nd Tier ships at most around. At that point the game was balanced. After a few more matches a Vetern joined with a Tier 5 ship. In a 5v5 match setup our complete team, all newbies in Tier 1 and Tier 2 ships, kept firing at that guys ship and he won. He literally outtanked all of our damage and killed us 1v5. It wasn't that we were bad, it was just that our ships weren't leveled enough. Not enough damage, not enough hull. The Tiers are balanced to each other but as newbie in this game you have lost the match before it even started.

It is the reason this game is dead. No one will put up the required hours to die their way to a max level Ship, just to be on equal footing with people that played the game much longer. I soon there after abandoned the match, as the realisation sunk in with the end of the promo weekend, that there just weren't enough newbies around anymore to have fun or level up.

The game's mechanics canabilse its own newbies, by making it completely impossible for them to have fun if they are in a match with people that played the game for much longer.

It was a good and interesting game, as long everything was balanced, but the low player base means you'll be joining matches with veterns in much stronger ships than your little dingy ship can measure up to. Its a fun game to play during sales, when new blood gets into the game, but as soon as the sale dies down, you are most likely going to deinstall the game.

Save your money.

reviewText:
While the game itself is fun to play, I can't safely recommend it to people because I geniunely dont think it's a safe purchase.

The game offers little to no singleplayer support, all gameplay is restricted to online multiplayer. Since the game has a questionable player base at best multiplayer is unreliable and can leave players waiting hours to play a game which may or may not start, leaving the game for the most part unplayable. If you do manage to get into a game it's very much an enjoyable (lengthy) experience.

Another rather major issue is that this game is no longer supported by tindalos interactive, meaning no updates, patches or technical support. The game also has various balancing issues and bugs which have not been addressed, as well as a lack of security which leads players to cheat the game into adding more player slots or worse. The game will not be changing anytime, so if you do plan on buying it be prepared to accept the game for what it is. This was not a random occurance, tindalos did run into hard times without the funds to continue employing full time programmers. Unfortunately this meant that they had to cut their losses with the stellar impact title to pursue other avenues.

Overall the game was a very ambitious project for a new development company to take onboard. Which unfortunately did not succeed in the end. While the game itself is actually rather good, it lacks the necessary support that a pure multiplayer moba needs to operate. It is a good game, but near impossible to play. Unfortunately in it's current age and state it's not worth buying.

Let me indulge into why I say Yes to this game.  One, the game's graphics are well done in specs for how much you can purchase it for.  There are very few glitches overall in the game which makes playability enjoyable.

Although, the lack of advertisement and support was this games down-fall.  It truly is a sad deal when a great game falls short.  Only for the fact of lost vision.

Currently you will find that the game has almost no one playing.  The ones that are playing are usually a group of four to eight people or more... that know each other and have the game.  Sadly, you'll be hard pressed to get people to game with.  There use to be a public TeamSpeak server for the game.  It was a form of assistance to help find games and teammates, as well as communication for in game.

This game could easily make a come-back if the creators and or current holders probably changed a few things... what I feel they could change to improve it.

1- Change how DLC works, for example new ships costing money is not a bad idea for a space battling game.  It is very much like League of Legends, Dota, or many others in this field of play.  Change it, but how?  You ask...  Well simple, currently many have bought the game so you might as well just let them have the DLC and Ships currently available.
While allowing new users to unlock these ships after meeting certain criteria.

1.5- Coming off the first improvement would be including a ranking system.  Example would be using Air-force or other forms of ranking to enlist Player's rank in games.  Someone who has played enough games to be seen as a veteran or a pro could be listed as a General.  Using XP and Wins to show their personal abilities.  You could even make it rank specific to ships.... meaning I could be a Commander Specialist on a Dreadnaught but a Rookie on a Destroyer.  Granted these ships already have a leveling system which enables survivability, but not game-breaking..

2- Servers, servers, server!  Find a deal or a means to get cheap and affordable server(s) that are not atrocious!  Heck, the current game building is not bad actually!  Although servers would allow them to create updates, new events, things that many games are now adopting.

3- Advertisement!  I honestly never even seen any advertisement effort.  If there was it was not enough.  DOTA and LoL did not get to where they are just by fan-base alone.  They sold themselves like an individual who willing sells them self for $2.00 an hour!  I mean seriously... Not enough advertisment!  When can you have too much advertisement?  When you have people laughing at the advertisment because they see it as silly... when it becomes SO normal that when it's missing they go... oh, hey... that's a new billboard?

3.5- Youtube, Google, Steam, Facebook, MySpace, and soo much more!  Heck, Youtube and Facebook you don't even need to pay for!  Be shameless in your advertisement, go all out if need be.  Blow the game up to superb expectations just to fall flat but then raise the game to those expectations once the money rolls!  Simple, no?

and my conclusion...  I just followed what a bunch of others have probably said about this game... those hard-core gaming members out there that enjoy a space battle.  This game is good for a top-down battle game in space.  It gives you that feeling at least... just depressing the game has essentially disappeared due to the current holders and or creators just giving up on it.  Sad days for such hard work that they put into a potentially fine game.

I rest my rant.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game. Do not pick it up. It is conceptionally flawed in a way that prevents any newbie to win against a veteran player. I bought this game during a sale, because its concept was nice. Back then, it was a few months after release, the game was almost dead already. (It is dead right now)

The game was fun for the first couple matches, because there were a good amount of newbies and 2nd Tier ships at most around. At that point the game was balanced. After a few more matches a Vetern joined with a Tier 5 ship. In a 5v5 match setup our complete team, all newbies in Tier 1 and Tier 2 ships, kept firing at that guys ship and he won. He literally outtanked all of our damage and killed us 1v5. It wasn't that we were bad, it was just that our ships weren't leveled enough. Not enough damage, not enough hull. The Tiers are balanced to each other but as newbie in this game you have lost the match before it even started.

It is the reason this game is dead. No one will put up the required hours to die their way to a max level Ship, just to be on equal footing with people that played the game much longer. I soon there after abandoned the match, as the realisation sunk in with the end of the promo weekend, that there just weren't enough newbies around anymore to have fun or level up.

The game's mechanics canabilse its own newbies, by making it completely impossible for them to have fun if they are in a match with people that played the game for much longer.

It was a good and interesting game, as long everything was balanced, but the low player base means you'll be joining matches with veterns in much stronger ships than your little dingy ship can measure up to. Its a fun game to play during sales, when new blood gets into the game, but as soon as the sale dies down, you are most likely going to deinstall the game.

Save your money.
